items.item_details: Education Code Section 72122 provides that student disciplinary matters be considered by the Board of Trustees in closed session unless the student submits a written request to the Board Secretary that the hearing of the governing board be held as a public meeting.  As of the time of posting the agenda, no such request had been received; however, the deadline for submission of the request had not yet passed.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The ETS Department refreshes and replaces computer equipment on a five-year cycle for student classroom labs as well as for faculty and staff.   Purchasing Services expects to issue large quantity purchase orders for Dell computer equipment in Fiscal Year 2015-2016, some that will exceed the current statutory bid threshold per purchase order. In accordance with the California Public Contract Code (PCC) Section 20651(a) through (d), only the governing board may authorize award of such purchase orders, and the board must award the orders to the lowest responsible bidder or reject all bids. However, in lieu of conducting a bid process, Public Contract Code (PCC) section 20652 provides that community college districts may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. 
	 
The required Dell products are available to the District on the Western States Contracting Alliance (WSCA) - NASPO (National Association of State Procurement Officials) contract.  WSCA-NASPO is a contracting consortium for state government departments, institutions, agencies and political subdivisions in the states of Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Minnesota, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington and Wyoming.  The WSCA-NASPO Master Price Agreement MNWNC-108 with Dell is currently valid through March 31, 2017 with mutually optional renewal years available. 
	 
WSCA-NASPO contract pricing is based upon the combined volume of several states and their political subdivisions. Each WSCA contract’s “Products and Services Schedule” (PSS) shows the maximum price offered to participating entities and provides that each entity may negotiate large order discounts. Additionally, the District is entitled to each vendor’s education discounts and may also benefit whenever the vendors announce promotional prices and/or general price reductions.  A bid based only upon the District’s anticipated purchases would be unlikely to result in lower prices than those available through the WSCA-NASPO contract. Prior to issuing each purchase order, District staff will contact the vendor to obtain a price quotation. The price quoted will be the lowest available to the District on that date for the specified products and quantities. 
 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: The Board is requested to authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to issue purchase orders in an aggregate amount that exceeds the legally mandated bid threshold to take advantage of the volume price discounts of WSCA-NASPO Master Agreement MNWNC-108 for Dell for as long as the contract is valid.
items.item_text: Authorization to Purchase Dell Computers in Excess of the Bid Threshold
items.item_text_raw: 3. Authorization to Purchase Dell Computers in Excess of the Bid Threshold

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District purchases office and classroom supplies in an aggregate amount that will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $86,000.00. The District can save on office supplies through the Foundation for California Community Colleges competitively bid, piggybackable contract with Office Depot. The contract features a competitively priced core item list with over 800 items and an annual 1% rebate with an additional up-to 50 item customizable core list.
	 
In accordance with the California Public Contract Code (PCC) Section 20651, only the governing board may authorize award of purchase orders that exceed the legally mandated bid threshold, and the board must award the orders to the lowest responsible bidder or reject all bids. However, in lieu of conducting a bid process, Public Contract Code (PCC) section 20652 provides that community districts may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. Office Depot products are available to the District through the Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) RFP# 15-003.  
	 
The Foundation for California Community Colleges is a statewide non-profit supporting the California Community College system. The Foundation serves as the official auxiliary to the California Community Colleges’ Board of Governors and the system wide Chancellor’s Office. The Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) RFP# 15-003 with Office Depot is currently valid through November 1, 2018 with mutual option to renew the Term for two (2) additional one (1) year terms.
	 
A bid based only upon the District’s anticipated purchases would be unlikely to result in lower prices than those available through the FCCC contract. FCCC contract pricing is based upon the combined volume of community colleges.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: The Board is requested to authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to issue purchase orders in an aggregate amount that exceeds the legally mandated bid threshold to take advantage of the volume price discounts of the Foundation for California Community College (FCCC) RFP#15-003 for office products from Office Depot for as long as the contract is valid.
items.item_text: Authorization to Purchase Office and Classroom Supplies from Office Depot in excess of the bid threshold
items.item_text_raw: 4. Authorization to Purchase Office and Classroom Supplies from Office Depot in excess of the bid threshold

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
FNTI is a back file conversion specialist in converting paper, microfilm and microfiche to electronic documents.  FNTI is financially stable and a division of Fidelity National Financial, a Fortune 400 company. In the last 10 years, FNTI has processed in excess of 10 billion records generated by state and local government. Greater than 300,000,000 of these records were scanned from paper, microfilm and microfiche captured at the clients location where the media is stored.
	 
On November 4, 2014, the district issued a purchase order to FNTI in the amount of $47,015 to scan the paper documents of Human Resources and Payroll departments. This purchase order was authorized by the Board based on the CMAS contract #3-12-36-0091A.  Subsequently, we completed this project on time, and both District Human Resources and Payroll departments are now operating with no paper storage moving forward.
	 
Based on the success of past projects and to continue improving the operating efficiency of the Admission and Records departments, both colleges now request ETS to move their legacy paper documents and microfiche student records to the Banner system. The volume of the paper and microfiche data is massive and span several decades.  ETS proposes to contract with FNTI to provide the scanning service to move this project forward.
	 
Both college leadership teams support this decision and will provide the necessary funding to initiate this project. The total one time cost to scan both colleges’ legacy documents is $140,849.
	 
De Anza College scan cost
$41,010.00
Foothill College scanning cost
$99,839.00
Total cost
$140,849.00
	 
Submitted by:
Joseph Moreau, Vice Chancellor of Technology, x6120
Additional contact names:
Chien Shih, Director of Information Systems & Operations, x 6139
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_text: Approval of FNTI Contract to Provide Scanning Services of Paper Documents for Uploading into Banner
items.item_text_raw: 5. Approval of FNTI Contract to Provide Scanning Services of Paper Documents for Uploading into Banner

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In conjunction with District Board Policy 3205, De Anza College allows community groups and organizations the use of the facilities when that use does not interfere with, infringe on or impede the educational process.
	 
The College strives to ensure diverse groups and organizations have access to the use of its facilities and believe in supporting a rich diversity of viewpoint, age, cultural background, race, purpose and social interaction.
	 
Saturday, October 17, 2015, Diwali Festival, Memorial Park 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.
The Bay Area Diwali Festival celebrated its 13th year at Memorial Park in Cupertino.  It was a free event for the entire community to enjoy and included many activities for all age groups, kids' zone, craft vendors, live entertainment. The purpose of the event was to bring the community together and celebrate multicultural understanding. Parking Lot A was requested for any overflow parking.
	 
Sunday, October 18, 2015, New Hope Chinese Cancer Care Foundation, VPAC, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.
The New Hope Chinese Cancer Center held its annual meeting at the Visual and Performing Arts Center at De Anza College.  The New Hope Cancer Care Foundation provides cancer patients free services including support groups, transportation, home visits, and educational sessions. Parking Lot A and adjacent parking to the VPAC was requested for 200 spaces.
	 
Monday, November 2, 2015, EEO & Faculty Diversity Summit, Campus Center, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.
This event is sponsored by the California Community Colleges Chancellor's Office and Academic Senate. It is anticipated that California community colleges will have a significant increase in full-time hiring. Historically, 20-30% of hires were from underrepresented communities. The summit's purpose is to seek feedback on best practices while providing training on the educational benefits of faculty diversity and elimination of bias. Parking Lots A, B, and C have been requested for over 100 meeting participants.
	 
De Anza College President Brian Murphy requests that the board approve the three waivers of parking fees for these three events.
	 
Submitted by:
  Brian Murphy, De Anza College President, ext. 8706
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: The De Anza College President requests the Board of Trustees waive parking fees for two community events at De Anza College on Saturday, October 17, and Sunday, October 18, and an educational event on Monday, November 2, 2015.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The California Community College Chancellor’s Office and the California Department of Education have $500 million appropriated through the State Budget to allocate funding for adult education. The funds will be provided to eligible consortia for the purpose of implementing regional plans for adult education. The intent of the Adult Education Block Grant was to expand and improve the provision of adult education via these consortia. (http://aebg.cccco.edu/About)
	 
The Adult Education Block Grant (AEBG) North Santa Clara County Student Transition Consortium (NSCCSTC) encompasses the Foothill-De Anza Community College District service area located in the heart of Silicon Valley and serves the communities of Cupertino, Los Altos, Los Altos Hills, Mountain View, Palo Alto, Sunnyvale and portions of San Jose.  This grant started in March 2014 and runs through June 2016.
	 
NSCCSTC is a partnership effort between the Foothill-De Anza Community College District (FHDA), Palo Alto Unified School District-Adult School (PAUSD), Fremont Union High School District Adult School (FUHSD), and the Mountain View-Los Altos Union High School District Adult School (MVLA). Our collective mission is to coordinate and integrate programs, create linkages, and develop regional plans to better serve the educational needs of adults in the region.
	 
The work for this grant will be accomplished through seven workgroups: Student Support Services, Professional Development, Curriculum Development, Articulation and Alignment, Community Based Organization and Local Government, Industry Leader and Employer Partnerships, and Data Systems.
	 
This memorandum of understanding (MOU) acknowledges all members support and assist in the next phase of the services of the Adult Education Block Grant from Aug 2015 – July 2016. The MOU also establishes the disbursement amounts given to each member.
	 
Foothill College disbursement amount is $199,212.
De Anza College disbursement amount is $199,212.
	 
Submitted by:
Kimberlee Messina, Interim President, Foothill College/Brian Murphy, President, De Anza College
Additional contact names:
Sharon Turner
Is backup provided?
No.
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College Interim President Kimberlee Messina and De Anza College President Brian Murphy recommend that the Board of Trustees approve the memorandum of understanding for distribution of the 2015-16 Adult Education Block Grant.
items.item_text: Foothill College and De Anza College - Memorandum of Understanding for Distribution of the 2015–16 Adult Education Block Grant
items.item_text_raw: 12. Foothill College and De Anza College - Memorandum of Understanding for Distribution of the 2015–16 Adult Education Block Grant

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College is required to create a yearly Student Success and Support Services Program (3SP) plan in response to the Seymour-Campbell Student Success Act (SCSSA) of 2012. The specific requirements in the SCSSA may be found in California Education Code, Sections 78210-78219. By prompting each California Community Colleges to write a 3SP plan, the legislature’s intent is to “increase California community college student access and success by providing effective core matriculation services, including orientation, assessment and placement, counseling, and other educational planning services, and academic interventions.” Consistent with the premise that student success is the responsibility of not only the student, but also of the institution as a whole, the overriding goal is for colleges to outline a specific plan to provide evidence-based, well-coordinated services that are integrated throughout both student services and instruction. Our efforts to increase student success must also give particular attention to at-risk students and to identifying and addressing issues of equity and disproportionate impact. With these principles in mind, we will coordinate with the Basic Skills and Student Equity Workgroups and the academic, classified, and student senates to develop a framework for cross-campus collaboration and coordination. We also realize that it will be imperative to actively include our part-time employees – whether they are faculty or staff – if our efforts are to be successful.
	 
We continue to work with our office of institutional research to evaluate the effectiveness of our efforts and revise our 3SP plan as appropriate in an ongoing effort to increase student success. This includes analysis through program review and other practices to gather data and evaluate outcomes with respect to orientation, assessment and placement, education plans, interventions for at-risk students, and follow-ups. 
	 
The current noncredit 3SP plan for 2015-2016 is attached.  
	 
Submitted by:
Laureen Balducci, Associate Vice President of Student Services, Foothill College
Additional contact names:
Denise Swett, VP Student Services; Carolyn Holcroft, Academic Senate President
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_text: Foothill Noncredit Student Success and Support Program (3SP) Plan (INFORMATION)
items.item_text_raw: 13. Foothill Noncredit Student Success and Support Program (3SP) Plan (INFORMATION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In early 2015, President Barack Obama announced the Americaâs College Promise proposal to make the first two years of community college free. Inspired by programs in Tennessee and Chicago, the proposal would create a partnership with states to help waive tuition for students enrolled in transfer or high-demand occupational training programs who attend at least half-time, maintain a 2.5 grade point average, and make steady progress toward completing their program. Momentum toward free community college is growing with new statewide programs started this year in Oregon and Minnesota; local programs initiated in Pennsylvania, Illinois, and Ohio; and legislation proposed in 11 additional states.
	 
To implement the goals of America's College Promise, an independent College Promise Advisory Board was formed in September to share current tuition-free models, recruit others to spread the message, and raise awareness about the importance of community colleges through the Heads Up America campaign. The advisory board is chaired by Jill Biden, vice-chaired by former Wyoming Governor Jim Geringer, and directed by former Under Secretary of Education and former Foothill-De Anza Community College District Chancellor Martha Kanter.
	 
California's College Promise Leadership Committee has asked all California community colleges to support the nationwide effort. A resolution in support of America's College Promise is attached for the governing board's consideration. 
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner, Chancellor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Judy Miner recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt the resolution in support of America's College Promise initiative.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District is dedicated to both satisfying the legal regulatory requirements of the Stipulated Judgment, which have been met, and continuing to develop strong environmental programs by going beyond the minimal compliance requirements.  Every year certain milestones are accomplished.  The specific ones include Regulatory Inspections with the Agencies (most notably the Department of Environmental Health), third party audit inspections with an environmental attorney and Internal self-inspections.  Hazardous waste management remains a large area of focus and continually evolves.  The Environmental Health, and Safety Department (EH&S) is actively involved with campus renovations and improvement projects and closures that occur in conjunction with renovations or departmental moves and the spending of G.O. Bond funds.  The EH&S department has improved each year by managing the permits, submittals and expenses of the department for the greatest value and least expense to the District.   
	 
Attached for your information is a report summarizing the activities of the EH&S department during 2014 and 2015.
	 
Submitted by:
 Karen Lauricella, Director, Environmental Health and Safety, x6146
Additional contact names:
 Kevin McElroy
Is backup provided?
 Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On January 12, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved a public access deed and an improvement maintenance agreement with the City of Sunnyvale (City).  In those agreements the District agreed to grant an easement for public passage through Innovation Way (half of which is owned by the District) and to maintain the street improvements within that easement.  Upon approval, the District informed the U.S. Department of Education of the easement grant, as required by the provisions of the property’s deed. 
	 
The U.S. Department of Education took exception to the easement, as the deed restricts the use of the property to educational functions, and by owning and maintaining a street the District violates that restriction, in their view.  At the prompting of the U.S. Department of Education, District staff proposed to the City that they simply accept ownership of the Innovation Way right-of-way.  In a response from the City Attorney, the City declined transfer of ownership but offered that the City would accept responsibility for maintaining the street.
	 
The U.S. Department of Education has agreed to this compromise provided that the District and the United States of America, acting through the Secretary of Education, enter into the attached Abrogation of Release of Restrictions agreement which modifies the deed restrictions.
	 
New public access and maintenance agreements between the City and the District, which will supersede those approved in January 2015, are being drafted by the City Attorney and will be submitted to the Board of Trustees at a later date.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Steve Kitchen, Executive Director of Facilities and Operations, recommends that the Board of Trustees approve the Abrogation and Release of Restrictions Agreement between the United States of America and the District.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District’s boiler (37 total), chiller (17 total), and cooling tower (8 total) systems heat and cool all classrooms, laboratories, and other building spaces on the Foothill and De Anza college campuses.  
					 
The District does not currently have a water treatment program in place for the maintenance of these systems and has been without one for more than four months.  Without regular treatment, the systems are subjected to improper chemical balancing of the water that can corrode the piping and also cause bacteria to grow. Therefore, Plant Services staff worked directly with Purchasing Services staff to develop a Request for Proposal (RFP) that would encompass the desired services required to perform one-time initial services for eddy-current corrosion testing, legionella bacteria testing, and cooling tower cleaning as well as on-going services for regular chemical treatment by qualified, licensed technicians of the boilers, chillers, and cooling towers.
					 
RFP #1738 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on September 2 and September 9, 2015 and notification of the RFP was also broadcasted through FHDA’s Purchasing web page. Additionally, Purchasing Services staff reached out to local vendors who provide these services to notify each of them of this opportunity. Five vendors attended the mandatory job walk on September 16th. Proposals were due on October 5, 2015 and four of the five vendors submitted responses.  
					 
Mr. Lester Lyons – Associate Director of Facilities & Operations and Purchasing Services staff reviewed and evaluated the proposals.  They were evaluated based upon five primary criteria, including qualifications (expertise/approach and proposed team members), and fees.  The firm that ranked the highest overall score is Advanced Chemical Technology Inc. (Advanced Chemical).
					 
District staff recommends that the Board of Trustees authorize a contract with Advanced Chemical for the described Water Treatment Program Services, including the one-time initial services. Costs for the initial 18-month contract are a total of $37,995 and the District has an option to extend the contract for a maximum of five years total. The Water Treatment Program Services will be paid for with Plant Services General Fund.
					 
FOOTHILL COLLEGE
$ 1,815 One-Time Services (Jan/Feb 2016)
$ 9,520 Initial 16-months Recurring Services
$11,335 Total
					 
DE ANZA COLLEGE
$ 4,260  One-Time Services (Jan/Feb 2016)
$22,400 Initial 16-months Recurring Services
$26,660 Total
					 
$37,995 TOTAL 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen -x6150, Lester Lyons – x5437, Gina Bailey – x6165
Is backup provided?
  No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize a contract with Advanced Chemical Technology Inc. for Water Treatment Program Services at both Foothill College and De Anza College based upon the scope of services and price structure provided in RFP #1738.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Request for Proposal #1738 – Water Treatment Program Services (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Radiologic Technology (RT) Program at Foothill College has a campus laboratory that includes an energized x-ray room where students work directly with faculty to perform physics experiments relating to core curriculum as well as x-ray radiographic phantoms to assess anatomic positioning and technical factors. The purchase of the AGFA Digital Radiography System will allow the RT students to achieve functioning knowledge of equipment used in hospitals today.  The equipment will also allow for increased discussion and application of patient dose reduction efforts.  This is an essential educational component due to increased public awareness of radiation exposure in the medical field as well as the professional commitment of the Radiologic Technology community to reducing radiation exposure to patients whenever possible.
	 
Request for Proposal (RFP) #1730 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on September 16 and September 23, 2015.  The RFP was posted through the FHDA portal on PlanetBids website. The proposals were due on October 13, 2015 and one vendor submitted a response, Agfa HealthCare Corporation. Purchasing Services staff and Rachelle Campbell, Foothill College Program Director of the Radiologic Technology program evaluated the response. The response from Agfa HealthCare Corporation was complete and thorough and meets the needs of the College. Agfa Healthcare Corporation provided the same services to other entities such as Oregon Health & Sciences University, Lucille Packard Children’s Hospital and Stanford Health Care.  
	 
The amount for the purchase and installation of a digital radiography system and the digital x-ray room upgrade is $129,881.  The purchase will be paid for using Measure C funds and it is within the amount budgeted for this acquisition.   
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Nanette Solvason, Rachelle Campbell, Annette Perez 
Is backup provided?
					No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to issue a purchase order in the amount of $129,881 to Agfa HealthCare Corporation in accordance with RFP #1730.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Request for Proposals #1730 - Purchase & Install a Digital Radiography System & Digital X-Ray Room Upgrade at Foothill College (ACTION)
